Zucchini Poem
the zucchini crouches
behind a broad green leaf
patient in her camouflage
imperialist tentacles of vine
are taking over the garden
shouting mine mine
like a woman waiting
for the revolution
the zucchini bides her time
rain falls in the night
first stealthy
then triumphant like a coup d'Ã©tat
come morning
the zucchini squats
swollen in the sunlight
proud of her belly
covering the earth
with ayellow flower behind her ear

Elizabeth Zelvin is a writer living in New York who has
poems appearing in Womanspirit and 13th Moon. She has
recently completed a book about an alternative marriage,
and among her other interests are "singing and song-writ-
ing, teaching creative movement, and trying to understand
the synthesis of anarchism and feminism."
